notes.text:
An update for thunderbird is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Mozilla Thunderbird is a standalone mail and newsgroup client.

This update upgrades Thunderbird to version 91.6.0.

Security Fix(es):

* Mozilla: Extensions could have bypassed permission confirmation during update (CVE-2022-22754)

* Mozilla: Memory safety bugs fixed in Firefox 97 and Firefox ESR 91.6 (CVE-2022-22764)

* Mozilla: Drag and dropping an image could have resulted in the dropped object being an executable (CVE-2022-22756)

* Mozilla: Sandboxed iframes could have executed script if the parent appended elements (CVE-2022-22759)

* Mozilla: Cross-Origin responses could be distinguished between script and non-script content-types (CVE-2022-22760)

* Mozilla: frame-ancestors Content Security Policy directive was not enforced for framed extension pages (CVE-2022-22761)

* Mozilla: Script Execution during invalid object state (CVE-2022-22763)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames

notes.text: A flaw was found in Mozilla. The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: If a user installed a particular type of extension, the extension could have auto-updated itself, and while doing so may have bypassed the prompt which grants the new version the new requested permissions.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2022-22754 Mozilla: Extensions could have bypassed permission confirmation during update
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2022-22754 Mozilla: Extensions could have bypassed permission confirmation during update

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

If a user was convinced to drag and drop an image to their desktop or other folder, the resulting object could have been changed into an executable script, which would have run arbitrary code after the user clicked it.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2022-22756 Mozilla: Drag and dropping an image could have resulted in the dropped object being an executable
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Product Security rates the severity of this flaw as determined by the Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2022-22756 Mozilla: Drag and dropping an image could have resulted in the dropped object being an executable

cwe.name: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

If a document created a sandboxed iframe without allow-scripts and subsequently appended an element to the iframe's document that, for example, had a JavaScript event handler - the event handler would have run despite the iframe's sandbox.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2022-22759 Mozilla: Sandboxed iframes could have executed script if the parent appended elements
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Product Security rates the severity of this flaw as determined by the Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2022-22759 Mozilla: Sandboxed iframes could have executed script if the parent appended elements

cwe.name: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere

notes.text: A flaw was found in Mozilla. The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: When importing resources using Web Workers, error messages would distinguish the difference between application/javascript responses and non-script responses. This could have been abused to learn information cross-origin.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2022-22760 Mozilla: Cross-Origin responses could be distinguished between script and non-script content-types
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2022-22760 Mozilla: Cross-Origin responses could be distinguished between script and non-script content-types

cwe.name: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

Web-accessible extension pages (pages with a moz-extension:// scheme) were not correctly enforcing the frame-ancestors directive when it was used in the Web Extension's Content Security Policy.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2022-22761 Mozilla: frame-ancestors Content Security Policy directive was not enforced for framed extension pages
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Product Security rates the severity of this flaw as determined by the Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2022-22761 Mozilla: frame-ancestors Content Security Policy directive was not enforced for framed extension pages

cwe.name: Improper Control of Generation of Code ('Code Injection')

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

When a worker was shut down, it was possible to cause the script to run late in the lifecycle, at a point where it should not be possible.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2022-22763 Mozilla: Script Execution during invalid object state
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Product Security rates the severity of this flaw as determined by the Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory.

cwe.name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

Mozilla developers and community members Paul Adenot and the Mozilla Fuzzing Team reported memory safety bugs present in Firefox 96 and Firefox ESR 91.5. Some of these bugs showed evidence of memory corruption, some of which could have been exploited to run arbitrary code.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2022-22764 Mozilla: Memory safety bugs fixed in Firefox 97 and Firefox ESR 91.6
